title: Ludington seeks more bonds for wastewater treatment plant upgrade
title_page: Ludington seeks more bonds for wastewater treatment plant upgrade
maintext:
Ludington’s wastewater treatment plant improvement project is one step closer to getting the required funding, said City Clerk Deborah Luskin.
The City of Ludington plans to borrow up to $5 million in additional federal bonds to pay for improvements to the city’s sewage disposal system, including the wastewater treatment plant on Sixth Street and the main pump station at Rath Avenue.
In December 2015, the city originally authorized up to $23.5 million in bonds to be borrowed for the project, but only an approximate $19.3 million in bonds remains available, since Ludington has already used $4.16 million to pay for other parts of the sewage system improvements.
Since the lowest contractor’s bid to do the wastewater treatment plant improvement work was about $20.6 million, the city is seeking the additional $5 million in bonds to cover the cost of the construction, as well as contingency funds, engineering and legal fees for the project.
If the additional bonds are authorized, the maximum principal amount of bonds capable of being borrowed for the project is $28.5 million. The bonds would be loaned from the U.S. Department of Agriculture Rural Development Agency, and they would most likely be paid back during a 40-year period at less than 3-percent interest, which is the same rate as the original bonds issued for the project, Luskin said.
To read the full story, check out the print or E-edition of Thursday’s Ludington Daily News.
